_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UNION CARBIDE CORPORATION is a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company.

South Charleston

The Union Carbide Corporation facilities at South Charleston, Institute, Polyolefins Process Research & Development, New Yard, and North Charleston Distribution Terminal share leveraged support and management and are collectively called West Virginia Operations (WVO).

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

West Virginia Operations is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release should occur, our highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also completely coordinated with the Kanawha Putnam Emergency Planning Committee which provides additional emergency response expertise.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The South Charleston site is a manufacturing facility that annually produces many different specialty chemicals. Most are intermediates used in other processes or sold to customers who convert them into finished products.  The North Charleston Distribution Terminal receives propylene oxide by barge, which is off-loaded into two Union Carbide Corporation-owned spheres for distribution to the South Charleston facility. While the storage spheres are owned by Union Carbide Corporation, the propylene oxide within is partially owned by both Union Carbide Corporation and Covestro. To take the most conservative approach, Union Carbide Corporation has included the total quantity of propylene oxide in the spheres in the maximum inventory calculation.  There is an inter-company demarcatio

n point after the transfer piping from the Union Carbide Corporation-owned spheres to Covestro-owned spheres.  Further, there are additional demarcations downstream of Covestro-owned equipment where they supply propylene oxide to plants owned by Union Carbide Corporation. 

The South Charleston site has two covered Processes, four Programs, and three regulated substances present at the stationary source.  The regulated substances are listed below:
Allyl Alcohol
Ethylene Oxide Propylene Oxide

Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection

Where worst and alternate case scenarios impacted additional receptors, all scenarios were included in the submittal. There is one (1) worst case toxic and four (4) alternative case toxic scenarios in this submittal. 

All scenarios were modeled using the RMP*Comp Tool with the exception of the propylene oxide WCS as the parameters for this scenario exceeded RMP*Comp capability.  As such, PHAST software was used to model the propylene oxide WCS.

REVISIONS TO THE PLAN
Revisions to the June 5, 2019 plan are being submitted for the following reasons:

Acquisition of the North Charleston Distribution Terminal propylene oxide assets.
The Union Carbide Corporation completed an acquisition of two propylene oxide spherical tanks and barge off-loading equipment.  This process is now included in Union Carbide Corporation Risk Management Plan.

Process Boundary and Maximum Inventory Verification.

Upon verification of RMP-covered process boundaries, it was determined that the Ethylene Oxide Distribution, Oxide Adducts, and Triton process were interconnected through ethylene oxide piping.  As such, this submittal contains two processes, South Charleston Plant and NCDT.
Maximum inventories were updated to include material up to inter-company demarcation points and newly acquired propylene oxide process at NCDT.



Changes were made to Section 1 to reflect updates to Owner or Operator and number of fulltime equivalent employees on site.    Unio

n Carbide Corporation acquired two spherical, pressurized tanks to store propylene oxide at its North Charleston Distribution Terminal.  This operation also includes barge unloading, for which a predictive worst-case scenario was considered.  Although not our typical shipment, the largest amount in a barge could be five (5) million pounds.  The worst-case scenario was based upon catastrophic failure of this largest vessel. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

South Charleston Plant has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases as defined by the RMP rule of regulated substances, during this period.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

UCCs general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule, OSHAs PSM standard, and implementation of Dow's Operating Discipline Management System. Key elements include:

Process Safety Information
We maintain a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include Material Safety Data Sheets for all the hazardous chemicals, Equipment Design Specification sheets, Reactive Chemicals Test results, and many others. This information is maintained up-to-date and is available to operating personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified, evaluated, and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses include:
Checklists, What If/Checklists (combined), Audits, Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analyses, Chemical
Exposure Index, Fire & Explosion Index, and Layers of Protection Analyses. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals. Any findings

related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Union Carbide Corporation maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
Our facility has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided on a continuing basis.

Mechanical Integrity
We carry out a highly documented Planned Preventative Maintenance Program (PPM) which provides checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps, and compressors. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Union Carbide facilities require management of all modifications to process equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions other than "like for like", by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of changes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and are trained to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new process

es and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at UCC. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Self-assessments and audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. Audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
UCC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a significant release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Union Carbide Corporation believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facilitys implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
Our company hires contractors to perform specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed. West Virginia Operations has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program provide

s the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Kanawha Putnam Emergency Planning Committee and the community.

The South Charleston facility carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.

To ensure proper functioning, quarterly emergency drills are conducted to enhance skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release. Critiques are held on drills and actual events. Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition to the on-site emergency squad, Dow has Distribution Emergency Response Teams throughout the United States that are available to distribution emergency within our area. 

Kanawha Putnam EPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We continue to implement projects to improve process safety as opportunities are identified via external regulatory changes and/or internal process safety program changes or evaluations.  The South Charleston site was re-certified as an OSHA VPP STAR site in 2018. The West Virginia Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.
